The frequency of the allele before selection is p = 1/8000. After mutation, each allele has a mutation rate μ, so the frequency becomes p' = p + μ. Selection then reduces the frequency based on the fitness of the genotypes. The genotype frequencies are p² (homozygous dominant) and 2pq (heterozygous). Fitness for dominant is 1 + s, for recessive is 1 - s. So the mean fitness W̄ = p²(1 + s) + 2pq(1 - s). The frequency after selection would be [p²(1 + s) + 2pq(1 - s)] / W̄. The change in allele frequency Δp is p' - p. Setting Δp = μ (since mutation introduces new alleles at rate μ) gives:

μ = p + μ - p - [p²(1 + s) + 2pq(1 - s)] / W̄
